Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Experimental Design and Analysis of Quantitative-Qualitative Responses in Manufacturing and Biomedical Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to establish a set of experimental design, analysis, and quality control methodologies for systems with both quantitative and qualitative (QQ) responses. Systems with QQ responses are commonly encountered in various manufacturing and biomedical applications. For example, in a thermal spray coating process, the coating quality is often measured by quantitative surface roughness and a qualitative coating failure indicator. Another example can be found in an organ transplant process, where the quantitative biopsy testing scores and doctors, qualitative evaluation are used to evaluate the health condition of the organ. The new methodologies are based on a joint modeling of the QQ responses to unveil the hidden relationship between the two types of the responses, and thus are more advantageous than the traditional methods that model the two types of responses separately. These methodologies will be tested and implemented in real case studies provided by industrial collaborators. The education plan will promote undergraduate and graduate students from the underrepresented groups to obtain the rigorous quality control training in various manufacturing and biomedical applications. The research results will be used to improve the quality in real industrial practices.

If successful, this research will lead to effective and reliable modeling, experimental design, monitoring and control of the systems with QQ responses. The joint modeling method considers constrained likelihood estimation with joint variable selection. It will further accommodate various complex scenarios including functional predictors, missing values, multiple responses, and nonlinear quality-process relationship. A Bayesian optimal design of QQ responses is planned to address the experimental design needs, which can be extended to sequential designs and designs for robust systems. Based on the modeling method, the model-oriented process monitoring will detect process changes, and identify root causes from the predictors or from the system itself. The quality improvement will be fulfilled by optimizing objectives accounting for the hidden relationship between the QQ responses. These methodologies will serve a set of powerful tools for manufacturing scale-up and biomedical quality improvement. Moreover, the educational plan will provide undergraduate and graduate students with various course modules and research opportunities. Real case studies will be used in lab sessions and undergraduate capstone projects. The research will equip students with critical thinking and hands-on skills in applied statistics, manufacturing, and biomedical systems. Research results will also be disseminated to academia and industry through publications, conferences, and workshops. A website will be established to share data, case studies, and advanced tools for promoting research collaboration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research project is to investigate complex systems with both quantitative and qualitative (QQ) response variables from the perspectives of experimental design, modeling, and quality control. Such systems are called QQ systems, which are widely encountered in advanced manufacturing and biomedical systems. Examples include manufacturing processes and biomedical processes generating good-or-not indicator together with continuous performance measure. For example, a thermal spray coating process will generate the coated surfaces with both the binary (i.e., success and failure) indicator subjectively determined by the end users, and the continuous surface roughness measured by sensors. As another example, organ presentation process will use qualitative evaluations for good, fair, and poor conditions given by the doctors, and infrared video streams for organ condition evaluation. There were significant gaps of knowledge to effectively design such experiments, and use the data-driven models for both QQ response variables for process modeling and quality assurance.

In this research project, the researchers investigated the methodologies of QQ models, which synergistically integrate modeling, data generation, and process monitoring for the QQ system. By exploiting the inherent characteristics in the QQ system, the developed methodologies significantly improve the modeling accuracy and quality control for QQ systems in comparison with traditional methodologies which model the QQ response separately. In the intellectual merit, the proposed joint modeling method, coupled with joint selection of important variables, can accommodate complex data structures involving functional and image data. A Bayesian optimal design for data collection and a Bayesian modeling of QQ responses were also investigated for the interface between the experimental design and data-driven modeling. The model-based process monitoring methodology was investigated to model a QQ system closely, enabling the detection of process changes in a timely manner. These methodologies advance the knowledge in manufacturing system modeling and biomedical quality improvement. These methodologies also advanced the development of handling the heterogeneous data structured in the era of data science. Twelve journal and conference papers were published in top journals and conferences in the engineering and statistics fields.

In broader impacts, the research team provided course modules, real case studies, and hand-on experiences to undergraduate and graduate students in their research exposure and thesis research. Outreach programs to Virginia high school female students have been provided to engage students to engineering majors, and improve their positive images of manufacturing. The research equips students with critical thinking and hands-on skills in applied statistics, manufacturing, and biomedical systems, especially on dealing with complex data from the real engineering challenges. Research results were also disseminated to academia and industry through publications, conferences, and invited university seminars.
